hold.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to have something in your hand, hands, or arms
hold.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Could you hold my bag for me?
He was holding a knife in one hand.
I held the baby in my arms.
They sat holding hands under a tree.
Max held her close and wiped away her tears.
hold.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to move your hand or something in your hand in a particular direction
hold.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He held out his hand to help her to her feet.
Hold the picture up so we can see it.
hold.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to have a meeting, party, election etc in a particular place or at a particular time
hold.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: This year’s conference will be held at the Hilton Hotel.
A thanksgiving ceremony was held to mark the occasion.
The funeral was held on a grey day in November.
In April, the president held talks with Chinese leaders.
hold.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to make something stay in a particular position
hold.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Lift your head off the floor and hold this position for five seconds.
A couple of screws should hold it in place.
We used rolled-up newspapers to hold the windows open.
Remember to hold your head up and keep your back straight.
hold.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to have a particular job or position, especially an important one
hold.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Do you really think he’s capable of holding such a responsible position?
Whoever is elected will hold office (=have an important political position) for four years.
She was the first woman to hold the office of Australian state premier.
The governor had held the post since 1989.
hold.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to have a particular title or record, because you have won a competition, are the best at something etc
hold.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: The programme still holds the record for the longest running TV series.
The last Briton to hold the title was Bert Nicholson.
hold.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to keep something to be used when it is needed
hold.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Further copies of the book are held in the library.
Weapons were held at various sites.
hold.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to agree not to give something such as a ticket, a place at a restaurant, a job etc to anyone except a particular person
hold.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: We can hold the reservation for you until next Friday.
You can’t expect them to hold the job open for much longer – you’ll have to decide whether you want it or not.
hold.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to keep someone somewhere, and not allow them to leave
hold somebody incommunicado (=keep someone somewhere and not allow them to communicate with anyone)
hold.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Police are holding two men in connection with the robbery.
A senior army officer was held hostage for four months.
hold.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to have a particular opinion or belief
hold.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: Experts hold varying opinions as to the causes of the disease.
This view is not widely held.
She was held to be one of the most talented actors of her time.
The judge held that the child’s interests in this case must come first.
hold.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to officially own or possess money, a document, a company etc
hold.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Do you hold a valid passport?
hold.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to have the space to contain a particular amount of something
hold.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: The tank should hold enough to last us a few days.
hold.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to be strong enough to support the weight of something or someone
hold.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: Careful! I’m not sure that branch will hold you.
The bridge didn’t look as though it would hold.
hold.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: to stay at a particular amount, level, or rate, or to make something do this
hold.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: The bank is holding interest rates at 4%.
Since then, the pound has held steady against the dollar.
Colourful pictures help hold the students’ interest.
hold.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: to continue to be true, good, available etc
hold.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: Twenty years on, his advice still holds good.
If our luck holds, we could reach the final.
hold.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: used in particular phrases to tell someone to wait or not to do something
hold.translation[0].definitions[15].note: hold your horses! (=used to tell someone to do something more slowly or carefully)
hold.translation[0].definitions[15].exam: I’ll have a tuna fish sandwich please – and hold the mayo (=do not give me any).
Hold it! We’re not quite ready.
hold.translation[0].definitions[16].defi: to wait until the person you have telephoned is ready to answer
hold.translation[0].definitions[16].exam: Mr Stevens is busy at the moment – would you like to hold?
Please hold the line while I transfer you.
hold.translation[0].definitions[17].defi: if an army holds a place, it controls it or defends it from attack
hold.translation[0].definitions[17].exam: The French army held the town for three days.
hold.translation[0].definitions[18].defi: to make a musical note continue for a particular length of time
hold.translation[0].definitions[19].defi: if the future holds something, that is what may happen
hold.translation[0].definitions[19].exam: Thousands of workers are waiting to see what the future holds.
hold.translation[0].definitions[20].exam: Many church services hold little appeal for modern tastes.
hold.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: to have something in your hand, hands, or arms
Maria came in holding a letter.
Can I hold the baby?
to hold something very tightly and not let it go
He gripped her arm so she couldn’t walk away.
Jenny gripped the side of the boat to steady herself.
clutch
to hold something tightly, especially because you do not want to drop or lose it
A businessman hurried past, clutching his briefcase.
The little girl clutched onto his hand.
clasp
to hold someone or something tightly, closing your fingers or arms around them
She was clasping a bunch of small summer flowers.
He clasped her in his arms and kissed her.
get/take hold of something
to take something in your hand or hands and hold it
I took hold of the handle and pulled as hard as I could.
Quickly – try and get hold of that frog!
grasp
to take hold of something firmly, especially in a determined way
She grasped the lowest branch and pulled herself up into the tree.
grab
to take hold of something suddenly and often violently
He grabbed my bag and ran off with it.
The other man grabbed hold of (=suddenly took hold of ) my arms and threatened me with a knife.
seize
to take hold of something suddenly and often violently
A police officer ran after him and seized the gun.
hang on (to something)
to hold on to something or someone tightly to support yourself
He hung on to the rail at the back of the motorbike.
Hang on tight!
keep hold of something
to continue to hold something
Greg was struggling to keep hold of the dog.
She tried to take her hand away but he kept hold of it.
hold.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: the action of holding something with your hands
hold.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: He tightened his hold, refusing to let her go.
Make sure you keep hold of my hand when we cross the road.
I took hold of her hand and gently led her away.
Grab hold of the rope and pull yourself up.
She released her tight hold on the dog.
hold.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: control, power, or influence over something or someone
hold.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: I’ve always kept a tight hold on our finances.
I realized that the woman had a hold over my father.
He struggled to get a hold of his emotions.
hold.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a particular position that you hold an opponent in, in a fight or a sport such as wrestling
hold.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: somewhere you can put your hands or feet to help you climb something
hold.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: The cliff was steep and it was difficult to find a hold.
hold.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: the part of a ship below the deck1(1) where goods are stored
hold.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: Rose had a tight hold of her hand.
Maria winced as Luke tightened his hold on her fingers.
Laughing, he loosened his hold until she could pull her arms free.
As soon as his fingers released their hold, Robyn turned and ran.
I had to run to keep hold of the leather strap.
Wallace took hold of Fred’s jacket and pulled him roughly backwards.
She grabbed hold of the letter and tore it open.
Nathan had hold of her hand again.
hold.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if you hold an investment, you own it
hold.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The group holds billions of dollars of junk bonds.
hold.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to keep an investment, rather than sell it
hold.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: I don’t sell anything. I buy stocks to hold.
hold.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to own part of company, asset etc
hold.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: The company also holds a 25 percent interest in a German refinery.
hold.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: to own a PATENT (=the right to profits from a product based on a new idea)
hold.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: Inventor Charles Fritz holds the patent to the Tripledge windshield wiper.
hold.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: This year’s conference will be held in Brighton.
hold.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: to keep supplies in a particular place
hold.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: The steel company holds stocks at the terminals in order to make just-in-time deliveries to local customers.
hold.translation[2].definitions[6].defin: to keep a price or other amount at a particular level
hold.translation[2].definitions[6].examp: The bank is holding interest rates at 4%.
hold.translation[2].definitions[7].defin: to remain at the same level
hold.translation[2].definitions[7].examp: Since then, the pound has held steady against the dollar.
hold.translation[2].definitions[8].defin: if something holds value or holds its value, it does not lose its value, or it loses value more slowly than you might expect
hold.translation[2].definitions[8].examp: The works of Magritte and Miro continue to hold their value at auctions despite the art-market slump.
In an increasingly disposable society, luxury cars are one of the few items that hold value.
hold.translation[2].definitions[9].defin: if a political party holds office, it governs a country
hold.translation[2].definitions[10].defi: to have an important job in the government or in a company
hold.translation[2].definitions[10].exam: The original directors of the company would hold office only for the first year of privatization.
hold.translation[2].definitions[11].exam: She has held the position of Chief Financial Officer for five years.
hold.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: the part of a ship or plane where goods are stored for transport
hold.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The Mega Borg had 38 million gallons of crude in its hold.
hold.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: if a company has a hold on a market or a large part of a market, it makes it difficult for others to compete
hold.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: They thought they had a pretty good hold on the computer market.
hold.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: if someone says that an investment is a hold, they mean that people who have it should keep it and not sell it, but that they should not buy any more of it
hold.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: He rates the stock a hold, but figures it ‘might go down before it goes up.’
